text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single framed full-width illustration at upper part of the page, with a single column of text directly beneath; wide blank margins on all sides, left margin decorated by a tree and birds touching the frame

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book-hand with regular pen-strokes, frequent use of ligatures and abbreviations

primary_colors: burnished gold leaf (halo, sail shields, frame lines)
color_scheme.color_usage: Gold reserved for divine halo and heraldic shields; deep blue for principal robes and sails, contrasting with green water; red accents on flag and pennants denote Christian symbolism; layered application of pigment with white highlights for wave crests; original pigments are well-preserved with minimal darkening of verdigris

Tree at left margin balances crew at right
Wavy sea at bottom anchors scene

decorative_elements: Single-line frame with alternating green and gold fillets
Left-margin tree with stylized foliage and perched birds
Row of wild animals (boars, lions) beneath waves in lower margin
Heraldic shields on sail forming repeating motif

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outline in brown ink with varied line weight for contours and details
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with minimal hatching, white lead highlights on waves and drapery folds
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping, no true linear perspective, depth implied by superimposition

content_theme.scene_description: Within a single rectangular frame, a wooden galley veers across a stylized green sea. Seven figures occupy the vessel: at the bow a seated haloed figure (John the Evangelist) leans over a bound codex, writing with a stylus; directly behind him a hooded companion steers a large oar; amidships two sailors haul on rigging to adjust a single large sail emblazoned with six gold shields; at the stern a helmsman grasps the rudder beam while another rower bends forward at a diagonal, oar in hand. Each figure wears period dress: long tunics with contrasting undergarments, pointed hoods or coifs, and belted waists. The Evangelist’s green cloak edged in gold indicates his authority. The sail’s heraldic shields and cross-topped pennant signal the seven Asian churches named in the caption below. Beneath the waves, wild boar and lion forms appear against a green ground, echoing terrestrial animal symbolism. A tall tree with angular foliage and two birds rising from its branches fills the left margin within the frame, providing a vertical counterpoint to the horizontal motion of the ship. The composition focuses attention on the act of writing as central action, with supporting figures arranged in a gently staggered hierarchy extending bow to stern.

secular: two sailors hauling sail ropes amidships

technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments remain vibrant with minimal flaking; slight cockling at folio edges; evidence of 19th-century flattening and margin reinforcement

Underdrawing visible in brown ink under UV light
Parallel ruling in plummet for text lines
Punchwork pattern in gold leaf background around shields

secondary_functions: Memory aid for letter-writing to the seven churches

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: Produced in a mid-13th-century Parisian workshop, this illumination exemplifies the high Gothic channel style associated with major scriptoria. The scene illustrates John the Evangelist on his symbolic voyage to the seven Asian churches, as enumerated in the Latin caption beneath: Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, Thyatira, Sardis, Philadelphia, and Laodicea. The use of ultramarine and burnished gold signals both theological importance and the patron’s wealth, while the heraldic shields on the sail visually codify the churches. Technically, the layered application of pigment over a precisely laid gesso ground, combined with underdrawing revealed under ultraviolet examination, demonstrates sophisticated workshop practices. Iconographically, the interplay of maritime imagery and apostolic writing conveys divine commissioning and ecclesial authority, aligning Old Testament typologies of pilgrimage with the New Testament’s epistolary mission. Visually, the centralized composition, framed by a tall tree and marginal beasts, merges narrative focus with decorative flourish. Comparatively, this folio shares affinities with the Apocalypse of St-Sever (BnF Latin 8878) in its rhythmic wave forms and schematic figures, yet introduces novel punchwork motifs within the shields. The manuscript thus reflects both traditional iconographic programs and innovative ornamental techniques, marking a transitional moment in Gothic illumination pedagogy.
